contents.context:
South Korea's overall industrial output in April fell for the fourth month in a row with the nation's manufacturing sector taking the biggest hit from COVID-19.
According to Statistics Korea on Friday, the country's overall industrial output plunged two-and-a-half percent on-month in April.
By sector, manufacturing saw a sharp on-month fall of six percent, its largest drop since 2008, on the back of dwindling demand for semiconductors and automobiles.
The operating rate also dropped by five.seven percentage points to around sixty-nine percent.

"While the service sector and retail sales experienced a light bump as the spread of COVID-19 slowed in April compared to February and March the COVID-19 outbreak and lockdowns in the U.S. and Europe led to a 6.4% drop in manufacturing production."

Retail sales jumped five.three percent from the previous month and facility investment posted a five percent increase on-month.
And the country might see an improved figure in these sectors over the following months.

"So, the worst part I think has passed in the month of April because of a lot of government actions and policy. The consumption and those service areas will probably pick up.."

And the government is already gearing up for the next step.

"The finance ministry announced Friday that the government will continue to promote what's being called the Korean version of the 'New Deal', along with other measures so that the country can become one of the global leaders in the post-COVID-19 era. Kim Sung-min, Arirang News."
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's industrial output plunges 2.5% m/m in April, manufacturing down 6%
Updated: 2020-05-29 17:02:51 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's overall industrial output in April fell for the fourth month in a row with the nation's manufacturing sector taking the biggest hit from COVID-19.
According to Statistics Korea on Friday, the country's overall industrial output plunged two-and-a-half percent on-month in April.
By sector, manufacturing saw a sharp on-month fall of six percent, its largest drop since 2008, on the back of dwindling demand for semiconductors and automobiles.
The operating rate also dropped by five.seven percentage points to around sixty-nine percent.

"While the service sector and retail sales experienced a light bump as the spread of COVID-19 slowed in April compared to February and March the COVID-19 outbreak and lockdowns in the U.S. and Europe led to a 6.4% drop in manufacturing production."

Retail sales jumped five.three percent from the previous month and facility investment posted a five percent increase on-month.
While the country has not escaped the impact of COVID-19, the government has also given a positive outlook for the following two months.
The official added that the government expects to see better data in May and June in which reflects the country's shift towards distancing in daily life measures and the governmental policies such as emergency relief payment.
The finance ministry also announced Friday that the government will continue to promote what's being called the Korean version of the 'New Deal', along with other measures so that the country can become one of the global leaders in the post-COVID-19 era.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's industrial output plunges 2.5% m/m in April, manufacturing down 6%
Updated: 2020-05-29 14:35:34 KST

contents.context:
To help local small and medium sized exporters struggling to deliver freight due to the pandemic, the South Korean government is providing chartered cargo flights.
Korea International Trade Association has joined up with the Ministry of Trade and Ministry of SMEs to arrange two special cargo flights bound for Narita, Japan and Frankfurt, Germany.
The flights are scheduled to depart South Korea on Saturday.
They are being offered to firms at about 25 percent cheaper than market price.
This is the second time that South Korea is providing cargo flights, it previously sent flights to China and Indonesia last month.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea sending chartered cargo flights to Japan and Germany
Updated: 2020-05-29 13:24:21 KST

contents.context:
Time now for an in-depth look at the market news this afternoon.
And for that, I'm joined on the line by Mr. Daniel Yoo, global strategist at Yuanta Securities.
Mr. Yoo, thank you for making time on this Friday.

Thank you.

On Wall Street, the markets were down Thursday after President Trump said he would be holding a press conference Friday, local time, about China. Investors expecting the tensions to rise. What's the story in the global markets today?

We have the U.S. Secretary of State and others saying that Hong Kong is no longer autonomous, that it's lost its special status and is effectively part of the mainland now. Hong Kong still is one of the financial hubs of Asia, so if the U.S. decides to formally remove its special status, what happens to the financial markets?

Korean stocks were down today too. Lots of factors at play, including the U.S.-China tensions. Tell us about the markets domestically.

Alright, Mr. Yoo.
We'll have to leave it there for today.
Thanks for coming on, and have a great weekend.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
In-depth: Global market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-29 13:23:03 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's trade ministry has announced that it will keep its anti-dumping duties on Japanese pneumatic valves.
The ministry said on Thursday that Seoul has notified both the World Trade Organization and Japan that South Korea has implemented all of the WTO's decisions and recommendations.
Back in 2015, South Korea imposed anti-dumping duties for five years on Japanese pneumatic valves, which are used in the auto industry and electronics sector.
In September last year, the WTO sided with Seoul in ten out of 13 casesafter Japan challenged the measure at the WTO's dispute settlement body.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to keep anti-dumping duties on Japanese pneumatic valves
Updated: 2020-05-29 10:07:40 KST

contents.context:
The COVID-19 pandemic continues to take a sledgehammer to South Korea's economywith the nation's manufacturing sector taking the biggest hit.
According to Statistics Korea, the country's overall industrial output plunged two-and-a-half percent on-month in April.
By sector, manufacturing saw a sharp on-month fall of six percent, its largest drop since 2008, on the back of dwindling demand for semiconductors and automobiles.
Service sector and retail sales both experienced a slight bump as the spread of COVID-19 slowed in April compared to March.
Retail sales jumped five.three percent from the previous month and facility investment posted a five percent increase on-month.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's industrial output plunged 2.5% m/m in April, manufacturing down 6%
Updated: 2020-05-29 10:06:40 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. economy shrank at an annual rate of 5-percent in the first three months this year-- faster than the initial estimate of 4.8 percent, and a far worse outcome is likely in Q2.
The Commerce Department reported Thursday that it was the biggest quarterly decline since an 8.4 percent drop in the last quarter of 2008 during the global financial crisis.
Economists say nationwide lockdowns and a massive uptick in unemployment will push growth down even further.
The White House says it will not release its official midyear economic update this summer, stressing that the underlying economic data would be too uncertain to convey a meaningful picture about the recovery.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
U.S. economy sank at 5% annual rate in Q1 due to COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-29 10:06:40 KST

contents.context:
And now to your market Wall Street saw a major sell-off in the last hour,.. sparked by President Trump announcing that he will be holding a press conference on Friday on China as geopolitical tensions ratchet up.
Erasing all the day's gains, the Dow Jones fell a nearly 150-points or point-6 percent while S&P 500 ended off point-2 percent at 30-29.
The NASDAQ dropped half-a-percent to close at 9,368.
Crude oil prices were little changed as U.S. crude inventories rose much more than expected, amid worries over fresh U.S.-China tensions.
Brent Crude picked up 2-percent.
WTI was up 2.7 percent to trade at 33-72 a barrel.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-29 06:06:11 KST

contents.context:
Japanese automaker Nissan Motor will withdraw from the South Korean market by December, amid weak sales caused by lingering anti-Japan sentiment and the COVID-19 pandemic.
The company says it will pull out the Nissan and its premium Infiniti brands due to worsening business environments at home and abroad.
The Japanese carmaker explained it will continue to provide after-sales services for South Korean owners of Nissan and Infiniti models for eight years through 2028.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Japanese automaker Nissan Motor to withdraw from S. Korea following sales drop
Updated: 2020-05-29 06:04:39 KST

contents.context:
To boost sluggish consumer spending, South Korea will hold a nationwide shopping festival for two weeks at the end of June.
Finance minister Hong Nam-ki said Thursday there'll be a variety of special sales online and discount coupons for use at small vendors and traditional markets.

"We expect this will help lift the burden on big and small distributors as well as local SMEs and small business owners who are struggling due to the pandemic."

And to support local auto parts firms, the government will set up a guarantee fund worth more than 4-hundred million U.S. dollars to prop up their sales.

"The government will protect the auto industry by supporting those with great technical capability but who struggle to thrive because their low credit rating prevents them from borrowing."

And to help carmakers, the government will buy around 9,5-hundred vehicles for its own use earlier than planned this year.
For the shipbuilding industry, the government will upgrade some 30 older vessels into eco-friendly ones.
They haven't forgotten sports either.
Loans for sports-related businesses will be expanded by around 16 million U.S. dollars.
The finance minister said he will announce plans early next month for revitalizing exports, including quarantine kits, in the upcoming policy direction for the second half of the year.
Kim Dami, Arirang News.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to hold nationwide shopping festival to boost consumption
Updated: 2020-05-28 17:07:45 KST

contents.context:
At the monetary policy board meeting for May on Thursday, the Bank of Korea forecast the local economy to contract in 2020, releasing its revised expected growth rate of negative 0.2 percent.
The revision, announced on Thursday, is far lower than its previous forecast of 2.1 percent back in February, down a whopping 2.3 percent.

"The optimistic scenario would be a small margin of positive growth but in case of the pessimistic scenario, it could result in a relatively large negative growth."

This is the BOK's first negative outlook since 2009 when it said the economic growth for that year would be negative 1.6 percent.
The only two previous times on record that actual GDP shrank were when Korea's GDP growth was negative 1.6 percent in 1980 and negative 5.1 percent in 1998.

Reflecting the grim outlook of the country's economy this year, the Bank of Korea cut its key interest rate to a historic low of point-5 percent, down 25 basis points.
The Bank of Korea slashed its benchmark rate to point-75 percent in March but kept it unchanged for April as the central bank opted to monitor the impact of measures already imposed.

The downgrade reflects contracted business activities both at home and abroad due to the pandemic.

"The rate was cut considering the projected sharp drop in inflation as the effect of the COVID-19 is expected to last a while."

The central bank's monetary policy board noted in a statement that because of the effect of COVID-19, consumption has contracted, exports have slowed and unemployment has risen, particularly in the service sector.

The Bank of Korea's governor said its forecasts assume that the outbreak will peak in the second quarter and then settle down, and that there won't be another large scale outbreak in South Korea.
Eum Ji-young Arirang News.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
BOK expects S. Korean economy to shrink 0.2% in 2020
Updated: 2020-05-28 17:07:45 KST

contents.context:
This is just coming in,… South Korea's central bank has cut its key interest rate to point-5 percent.
The rate cut is likely in response to sluggish exports and a contraction in domestic consumption as a result of the COVID-19 outbreak.
The Bank of Korea cut its key interest rate to a historic low of point-75 percent in March but kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged for April as the central bank opted to monitor the impact of measures already imposed.
The monetary policy board is also due to release the country's expected economic growth rate.
We'll have more details during our next newscast at noon, Korea time.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
BOK cuts interest rate by 25 basis point to 0.5% in May
Updated: 2020-05-28 14:30:59 KST
